Also: A single gatekeeper is, at the very least, easy to regulate than millions of individual devs. Look at GDPR for an example, where companies have wildly different interpretations on compliant behaviour. Think how MS‚Äô behaviour was curbed by its consent decree... :)

It is more about defining what the rule set is for software -- is that a static set of rules, which would just be the APIs but there is no way to avoid the use of APIs in ways not intended (I had 25 tweets on that yesterday). So then you need an enforcement system. Or air gap.

Whoever builds and maintains that model must have the ability to either auto-deploy to patch privacy holes (otherwise it‚Äôs inherently insecure) or revoke the ability of malicious code to run. Neither is something that would fit your ideal.

What you‚Äôre asking for is a chimaera: a decentralised privacy (not the same as security) model with all the advantages of having a gatekeeper. I don‚Äôt think that‚Äôs technically possible, partly because someone has to (at least) build and maintain the software.

Perhaps like when we use ATM/credit cards. They retain the right for whatever reason to stop them from working at any time--and there isn't a card alternative that does not provide that centralized security.

Nilay is right to a large degree. You can turn off your browser, defender and Windows Update and then you run in isolation. BUT it is also the case that an app can stop working any time the system is updated, at the discretion of the platform (or by accident).

All of this only happens if you to accept centralized security models, which no desktop platform forces you to do in order to run apps. We made a startling set of tradeoffs around security starting with mobile and they are worth constant scrutiny

It is common for some to look at competing products and describe a product with the ‚Äúpositive‚Äù attributes of both that they desire (CEOs do this all the time during development). The market doesn‚Äôt create those for many reasons. Just like context X with no ads isn‚Äôt an option.

When @Apple moved to @Qualcomm chips in the iPhone in 2011, it said it would use Qualcomm modems exclusively in the short term -- but it always planned to have a second chip supplier, Jeff Williams testifies at @FTC trial

When @Apple went to @Qualcomm to supply modems for the iPhone in 2011, it found it was going to pay more than the previous $7.50/device royalty fee, plus a higher rate for the processor than what @Infineon charged, Jeff Williams says during @FTC trial

We're going way back to my early days covering tech and the battle of GSM vs. CDMA. They're competing 3G techs. @ATT favors GMS, @verizon favors CDMA). @Apple had to use @Qualcomm chips to connect iPhones to CDMA networks. @FTC
.@Apple had wanted to pay a 5% fee for the value of the baseband chip, which was $30. So it wanted to pay $1.50 royalty per iPhone to @Qualcomm instead of $7.50, Jeff Williams says at @FTC case

.@Qualcomm initially planned to charge @Apple's contract mfgs a 5% royalty on every iPhone sold (which would equate to about $12-$20/device). But it reached a rebate agreement to drop that rate to $7.50 per iPhone, Jeff Williams testifies

When @Apple was making the first iPhone, it looked at licensing @Qualcomm's standard essential patents. But Qualcomm said Apple would have to cross license its IP to $APPL -- but Apple would still have to pay, Jeff Williams testifies at @FTC trial
Jeff Williams is @Tim_Cook's No. 2 at @Apple. He was part of the team that launched the first iPhone. @FTC @Qualcomm $QCOM
